instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D9701: What is D9701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.D7701: What is D7701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no backlight
threads.message: I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damaged.  Ran it through ultrasonic and replaced nasty looking <CAPACITOR>C7796</CAPACITOR>, but still no backlight.  Checked bklt fuse its fine, <CAPACITOR>C7796</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7797</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7799</CAPACITOR> all measuring correctly.  I can not seem to find anything else wrong. Please help.

threads.message: Values on diode mode before <DIODE>D9701</DIODE> and after <DIODE>D9701</DIODE> to GND?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no backlight
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no backlight
threads.message: What is the voltage output on <CAPACITOR>C7799</CAPACITOR>? If it is 8.4 then I suspect a dead <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no backlight
threads.message:
.411 is too low. .400 to .475 signify bad feedback line to <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>. 0.511-0.545 is what you want after the diode. What does ball A5 for feedback on <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> look like?

Also, what is your backlight voltage? 0v, 8.4v, 19v, 27v, or 49v?

0v means break in line or being told to stay off altogether.

8.4v means no boosting, but continuity all the way through on the top of the line from coil to diode, diode to output, etc.

19v means missing pwm or bad <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>

27v means we're blind :)

49v means bad lcd/lcd backlight cable inside assembly is not plugged in/bad cable.

threads.message: voltage is 8.4v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no backlight
threads.message:
[QUOTE="larossmann, post: 270"].411 is too low. .400 to .475 signify bad feedback line to <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>. 0.511-0.545 is what you want after the diode. What does ball A5 for feedback on <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> look like?

Also, what is your backlight voltage? 0v, 8.4v, 19v, 27v, or 49v?

0v means break in line or being told to stay off altogether.

[COLOR=#B22222]8.4v means no boosting, but continuity all the way through on the top of the line from coil to diode, diode to output, etc.[/COLOR]

19v means missing pwm or bad <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>

27v means we're blind :)

49v means bad lcd/lcd backlight cable inside assembly is not plugged in/bad cable.[/QUOTE]

8.4v means no boosting

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no backlight
threads.message: I just want to verify <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> is bad before replacing it

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no backlight
threads.message: continuity test in diode mode, if beeps is ok if not is open, if you press "N" key on landrex  and give the name of the net you are looking for, it will tell you all the places where this net should be...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no backlight
threads.message: thank you!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no backlight
threads.message: One way to find out for sure is to pull the 8550 and measure feedback lines before and after diode to the 8550 pads. But before you do that you can check <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>. I still think this is going to be a bad 8550.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no backlight
threads.message: The new LP8550s come pre balled. You may not have enough solder on all of the pins of the pulled <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>. I'm having similar issue...just waiting on the new LP8550s so I can test the issue before posting a thread about it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no backlight
threads.message: Reballing the <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> requires a level of skill not worth investing for a chip that is $1.61 new with balls. Try again with new chip.
